Wie richte ich die Gruppensynchronisierung zwischen XWiki und meinem OpenID Connect-Anbieter ein?
Ich verwende einen OpenID Connect-Anbieter, der Gruppenansprüche unterstützt, und ich möchte diese Gruppen mit XWiki-Gruppen synchronisieren. Wie ist der Prozess für die Einrichtung?
expected_answer:
Um die Gruppensynchronisierung zwischen XWiki und Ihrem OpenID Connect-Anbieter einzurichten:
1. Suchen Sie die Datei `xwiki.properties` im Installationsverzeichnis von XWiki.
2. Öffnen Sie die Datei mit einem Texteditor.
3. Konfigurieren Sie die Gruppensynchronisierung, indem Sie die Eigenschaft `oidc.groups.claim` auf den Namen des Anspruchs setzen, den Ihr OpenID Connect-Anbieter verwendet, um Gruppeninformationen zu senden. Zum Beispiel:
```java
#-# Der Name des Anspruchs, der verwendet wird, um die Liste der Gruppen zu erhalten, zu denen der Benutzer gehört.
# oidc.groups.claim=groups
```
Ersetzen Sie `groups` durch den tatsächlichen Anspruchsnamen, der von Ihrem OpenID Connect-Anbieter bereitgestellt wird.
1. Wenn Ihr OpenID Connect-Anbieter Gruppenmitgliedschaften als einzelnes Wertattribut sendet, das durch ein bestimmtes Zeichen (z. B. ein Komma) getrennt ist, konfigurieren Sie die Eigenschaft `oidc.groups.separator` mit dem entsprechenden Zeichen:
```java
#-# Wenn der Identitätsanbieter Gruppenmitgliedschaften als einzelnes Wertattribut zurückgibt, das mit einem Zeichen getrennt ist, zum Beispiel:
# oidc.groups.separator=,
```
Ersetzen Sie das Komma durch das tatsächliche Trennzeichen, das von Ihrem Anbieter verwendet wird.
1. Wenn Sie die synchronisierten Gruppen bestimmten XWiki-Gruppen zuordnen möchten, konfigurieren Sie die Eigenschaft `oidc.groups.mapping` mit den entsprechenden Zuordnungen:
```java
# oidc.groups.mapping=XWiki."MyXWikiGroup"=group1
# oidc.groups.mapping=XWiki."MyXWikiGroup2"=group2
```
Ersetzen Sie `MyXWikiGroup` und `MyXWikiGroup2` durch die Namen der XWiki-Gruppen, die Sie zuordnen möchten, und `group1` und `group2` durch die tatsächlichen Gruppennamen, die von Ihrem OpenID Connect-Anbieter bereitgestellt werden.
1. Speichern Sie die Datei `xwiki.properties` und starten Sie Ihre XWiki-Instanz neu, damit die Änderungen wirksam werden.

To set up group synchronization between XWiki and your OpenID Connect provider, you need to follow these steps:

1. **Configure your OpenID Connect provider**: Ensure that your OpenID Connect provider supports group claims. You will need to obtain the endpoint for retrieving group information for a user. This is often in the form of a URL that returns a JSON or XML document containing the user's groups.

2. **Create a custom XWiki authentication script**: XWiki allows you to create custom authentication scripts. You will need to write a script that, given a user's OpenID Connect identifier, can retrieve the user's groups from the OpenID Connect provider. This script should be written in a language that XWiki supports, such as Java or Groovy.

3. **Configure XWiki to use the custom authentication script**: Once the custom authentication script is written, you will need to configure XWiki to use it. This is done in the `xwiki.properties` file. You will set the `xwiki.authentication.script` property to the path of your custom authentication script.

4. **Configure group synchronization in XWiki**: After XWiki is configured to use the custom authentication script, you can configure group synchronization. This is also done in the `xwiki.properties` file. You will set the `xwiki.group.mapping` property to a script that maps OpenID Connect groups to XWiki groups. This script should use the results of the custom authentication script to determine the user's groups.

5. **Test the group synchronization**: Finally, you should test the group synchronization to ensure it is working correctly. You can do this by creating a new user in your OpenID Connect provider, adding them to a group, and then logging into XWiki with that user. The user should have the same group permissions in XWiki as they do in the OpenID Connect provider.

Please note that this is a general guide and the exact steps may vary depending on the specifics of your OpenID Connect provider and your XWiki configuration. You may need to consult the documentation for your OpenID Connect provider and XWiki for more detailed instructions.

# openoffice.autoStart=falseFor the profilePath configuration option, you need to have an OpenOffice profile directory created somewhere on the system. This can be a problem in server environments where launching OpenOffice is not an option. In such situations you can create an OpenOffice profile on a local computer and upload it to the server running XE.

Once XWiki is configured in this manner, an OpenOffice server must be manually started as a separate process. You can issue the following command to accomplish this:

soffice -headless -accept="socket,host=127.0.0.1,port=8100;urp;" -nofirststartwizardDon't forget to replace <soffice> with the path to your OpenOffice executable. More information regarding OpenOffice server deployment is provided [here](http://www.artofsolving.com/node/10). Also note that the Office Importer admin UI will change reflecting the new configuration as shown below:

![admin2.png](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/download/Extension/Office%20Importer%20Application/admin2.png?rev=1.1)

Linux users may refer to additional installation notes [here](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Office%20Importer%20Application%20Linux).

## Auto start / Auto connect (feature)

This feature was introduced beginning with the XWiki 1.8.4 version. With this option enabled, you don't need to worry about starting / connecting the OpenOffice server from the Office Importer admin UI every time you restart XE. XWiki is written in Java/Java EE. As such it scales as well as Java scales.

# Multi Tenancy

XWiki supports the ability to run hundreds and even thousands of wikis on the same JVM (i.e. same webapp).

Some examples:

* [MyXWiki](http://myxwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Main/WebHome) currently hosts over 170 wikis on a single JVM
* [XWiki SAS Cloud](http://network.xwiki.com) currently hosts 1000+ wikis (but on several JVMs)

See the tutorial on [how to configure multi-tenancy](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/AdminGuide/Virtualization) to learn more.

# Clustering

XWiki provides an easy way to setup clustered instances of XWiki based on network events distribution. Clustering allows for 2 use cases:

* Load distribution on several JVMs
* Failover since if a machine is down the other ones are still available

See [Clustering](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/AdminGuide/Clustering) for more details.

First generation wikis are used to collaborate on content. Second generation wikis (a.k.a Structured and Applications Wikis) can be used to create collaborative web applications (by using the wiki paradigm and editing wiki pages). XWiki can be used either as a first generation wiki or a second generation one.
 
## First generation wikis

 Focused on **content** creation. Some example of features:
 * #### [Page editing](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/PageEditing)


Use simple wiki syntax to format text, create tables, create links, display images, etc. Alternatively use a powerful WYSIWYG editor to edit the content of pages.
* #### [Version Control](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/VersionControl)


Any change made in XWiki is saved under version control, meaning you can view any previous version of a page, compare different versions or rollback to any past version.
* #### [Rights](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/RightsManagement)


Control who can view, edit or delete pages in a flexible manner. Apply rights to a page, its children or an entire wiki.
* #### [Search](https://extensions.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Extension/Search%20Application)


Allows searching on the full wiki using wildcards, faceting search results, getting search result RSS feeds and more.
* #### [Exports](https://www.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Documentation/UserGuide/Features/Exports)


Export wiki pages to PDF, ODT, RTF, XML or HTML.
